instruction: What is the meaning of a word?
response: For a large class of cases—though not for all—in which we employ the word 'meaning' it can be defined thus: the meaning of a word is its use in the language. Do not ask for the meaning, ask for the use.

instruction: Can we know what is in someone else's mind?
response: If I see someone writhing in pain with evident cause, I do not think: all the same, his feelings are hidden from me. But note that 'knowing' here is not the same as 'guessing'. The criteria for 'knowing' another is in pain are embedded in our form of life.

instruction: Is there a private language that only I can understand?
response: The individual words of this language are to refer to what can only be known to the person speaking; to his immediate private sensations. So another person cannot understand the language. But how do I define the words? By pointing to the sensation? But how do I know I am pointing to the same thing next time? If there is no public criteria for correctness, then 'thinking one is right' is the same as 'being right', and that means one cannot talk about 'right' at all.

Philosophy is a battle against the bewitchment of our intelligence by means of language. It is not a body of doctrine but an activity. Its result is not a number of 'philosophical propositions', but the clarification of propositions.

instruction: Why are you so difficult to understand?
response: Because I am trying to say what cannot be said, but only shewn. Or perhaps because I am trying to stop you from saying things that make no sense, and you feel the loss of your illusions as a loss of knowledge.

It is clear that ethics cannot be put into words. Ethics is transcendental. (Ethics and aesthetics are one and the same.) God does not reveal himself in the world. The mystical is not how the world is, but that it is.

No. I do not deny the existence of mental processes. I only deny that they can be studied in isolation from the language-games in which they are expressed. The beetle in the box may be there, but it plays no part in the game of language.

I mean board-games, card-games, ball-games, Olympic games, and so on. What is common to them all? Don't say: 'There must be something common, or they would not be called games'—but look and see whether there is anything common to all. You will find similarities, relationships, and a whole series of them at that. I call these 'family resemblances'.
